caseTitle: REPUBLIC v. OPANYIN EKRA KWAME & ANOR
summary: This Court of Appeal case from Ghana addressed whether the appellants, Opanyin Ekra Kwame and another, were rightly convicted of contempt for failing to surrender the 'black stool' and all 'Bombae drums' of Kwesimintim to the Western Regional House of Chiefs. The High Court had convicted them based solely on affidavits, particularly one from the Registrar of the House of Chiefs, who claimed the surrendered stool was a kitchen stool and only three of six drums were returned. The appellants protested at the hearing that they had fully complied. The Court of Appeal held that contempt being quasi-criminal requires proof beyond reasonable doubt, and it was erroneous to base conviction solely on untested affidavit evidence without oral testimony or cross-examination, especially when material facts were disputed. The trial judge’s reliance on the Registrar’s unchallenged affidavit was deemed inappropriate, as the appellants had orally contested the claims. The appeal was allowed, and the conviction quashed due to procedural unfairness and failure to meet the required standard of proof.
verdict: The appeal was allowed and the conviction for contempt was quashed due to insufficient evidence and failure to meet the standard of proof beyond reasonable doubt.
citations: Republic v Bekoe and Others Ex Parte Adjei (1982-83) GLR 91
Republic v Georgina Asare Ex Parte Annor-Yeboah & Anor. CA dated 20th May, 2001 (unreported)
rationaleHighlights: Contempt cases require proof beyond reasonable doubt, akin to criminal trials.
Reliance on unchallenged affidavits without oral evidence or cross-examination is insufficient for conviction in contempt cases.
The trial judge erred in accepting the Registrar's affidavit as conclusive without testing its credibility.
An appeal filed out of time does not automatically stay execution of an order.
Ambiguity in the original order regarding number of drums contributed to the dispute.
Failure to allow proper challenge to affidavit evidence undermines fair trial principles.
Court disapproved of treating contempt cases as purely affidavit-based proceedings.
Protestations by appellants at hearing constituted sufficient contestation of facts.
